author: sky.cactus
content: I have long lobbied that if a bug in a majority client resulted in a fork, regardless of the severity of the issue we (the community) should refuse to follow it.

author: sky.cactus
content: Anyone who runs a majority client should understand that they are just putting themselves at risk and they will be punished if those risks come to pass, they will not be bailed out.

author: sky.cactus
content: That being said, I believe client diversity has improved to the point where this isn't a huge risk anymore.

author: sonic.1337
content:
> That being said, I believe client diversity has improved to the point where this isn't a huge risk anymore.
I strongly disagree. The data I have collected so far (by asking the services/pools), seems to result with Geth at around 80 - 90%.
As you likely already know, it's not possible to get a full dataset, but assuming the data is somewhat reliable, we are still way above 2/3 Geth usage.
The project is work in progress, so I don't want to make a final statement yet.

author: sky.cactus
content: If that is true then I will return to my original argument that there should be no bailout for a consensus bug in Geth.

author: sky.cactus
content: If there is a 2 week long fork of Geth behaving different from minority clients, then Geth will get patched and rolled back 2 weeks.

author: sky.cactus
content: IMO this point should be made *very* clearly to everyone, especially infrastructure providers and exchanges.  There is no excuse at this point for continuing to use a majority client.
